title: Parkmont School
text:
Parkmont School is a <a href="private%20school">private school</a>, located at 4842 16th St NW in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, DC</a>., that serves grades 6-12. Parkmont was founded in 1972, by a parent group in <a href="McLean%2C%20Virginia">McLean</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>, as a cooperative <a href="middle%20school">middle school</a>. Parkmont was designed for parents looking for <a href="alternative%20education">alternative education</a> for their child. The school uses more of a hands-on, individual, and dynamic approach than more traditional schools. Parkmont is non-sectarian and an <a href="Association%20of%20Independent%20Maryland%20and%20DC%20Schools">Association of Independent Maryland and DC Schools</a> accredited school.
History.
Parkmont was founded in 1972, as a <a href="cooperative">cooperative</a> parent-run middle school and became a board-operated <a href="501%28c%29%283%29%20organization">501(c)(3)</a> in 1995. The school derived its name from the Parkway Program (Park) and the philosophy of <a href="Montessori%20education">Montessori education</a> (mont).
Until 1977, Parkmont School was located at 16670 Chain Bridge Road in McLean, Virginia. With the help of a $100,000 <a href="Grant%20%28money%29">grant</a>, the school was able to relocate to Washington, D.C., to take better advantage of the educational opportunities available in the city. 
In the spring of 1991, Parkmont School merged with Somerset School and moved to its current home.
Parkmont teaching method.
The Parkmont School's approach, in the unique way they're educating their students, can be found in their <a href="mission%20statement">mission statement</a>:
This broad use of educating students can be found in the <a href="Montessori%20education">Montessori</a> Philosophy, founded by the progressive educator, <a href="Maria%20Montessori">Maria Montessori</a> (1870-1952). The Montessori philosophy is based on "supporting the complete development of the child as they progress from birth to adulthood. It takes the broad vision of education as an aid for life."
One of Montessori's many accomplishments was the <a href="Montessori%20method">Montessori method</a>. This is a method of education for young children that stresses the development of a child's initiative and natural abilities, especially through practical play. This method allowed children to develop at their own pace and provided educators with a new understanding of child development.
